    Introduction

    In this tutorial, we will learn how to install and configure a mesh network using OpenWrt and the layer-2 implementation of the Better Approach to Mobile Adhoc Networking, called batman-adv. All the software mentioned here is free and open-source, as opposed to commercial alternatives (UniFi Mesh or Google’s Nest Wifi).

    Why did I write this guide?

    Even though the concept of mesh networks has been around for quite some time now (REF), the documentation of its implementation is still scarce. I don’t feel qualified to speculate on why this is so but I find it odd because many of the radio devices found in popular wifi routers (REF) actually support mesh networking–but the original firmware often doesn’t give users the option to use such mode of operation. (You can even run a mesh network with something as cheap and small as an ESP32.) My intention with this guide is to help closing the gap between concept and implementation of mesh networking using software that anyone can download and install on cheap, commonly available hardware.

    but while researching recently, I found it strange that aside from the commercial solutions, the documentation about implementing mesh networks is scarce and often outdated.

    write a little about the motivation for this guide:

    • Such a presentation could then be used as a template for more advanced implementations of a mesh network. While researching, I found outdated information and the good content is often times spread across multiple forum posts. This motivated me to write a simple guide for anyone who wants to experiment building their own mesh without relying on commercial solutions.

    Objectives

    This is more of a hands-on, how-to guide to building mesh networks for home users than a review about the concepts related to mesh networkings.

    Why mesh?

    • Minimal infra-structure
    • Smart, multi-point connections
    • Flexible network topologies
    • Self-discovery
    • Self-healing
    • High availability

    Objectives

    1. Get familiar with /etc/config/ files in OpenWrt devices and how to edit them with vi.
    2. Learn how to configure OpenWrt devices to play one of three possible roles: (a) dumb mesh node, (b) bridge node, or (c) gateway node.
    3. Install and configure batman-adv on an OpenWrt device using the opkg package manager.
    4. Learn how to use batctl to test, debug, and monitor connectivity within the mesh.
    5. Add encryption to the mesh network with the package wpad-mesh-openssl.
    6. Use VLANs to create a Default, IoT, and Guest networks within the mesh using batman-adv.

    top

    Regarding the hardware, all mesh nodes used were the TP-Link WR-1043ND v1.8 just to illustrate the various implementations (and because they are very cheap, too) but the general ideas presented here should apply to any radio device that meets the following criteria:

    1. Compatible with the latest OpenWRT version (list of hardware);
    2. Supports the mesh point mode of operation. (This point is covered in more detail in this part of the tutorial.)

    If you’re looking for devices to buy and experiment on, my suggestion is to look for dual-band wifi routers to allow a better segmentation of the wifi networks. Now, if you can afford spending more, look for tri-band devices. Netgear and Linksys have solid options that are compatible with OpenWrt. That said, most home users will be just fine with a uni-band router. For a brand reference, TP-Link has good and cheap devices that can be used in a mesh networking project without (too many) issues.

    Alternatively, you can run OpenWrt with a virtual machine or as a docker container. For single-board computer fans like me, you can run OpenWrt with most of them and then use a combination of on-board wifi and USB adapter to create a powerful mesh node. (ClearFog boards look like good candidates for such a project, for example.) Of course, you can run OpenWrt on baremetal amd64 machines, which will give you a ton of options to put together an impressive mesh device.

    Other similar mesh solutions

    If you find this guide a little bit overwhelming but you’re still curious about mesh networking, take a look at these other solutions (alphabetical order):

    • Commotion Wireless
    • LibreMesh

    They have pre-configured images that will work “out of the box” with compatible devices.
